speaker: Chris
text: So it's very responsive to the gravitational field.

speaker: Chris
text: So now we can ask about Alice.

speaker: Chris
text: Right.

speaker: Chris
text: Alice is also embedded in this gravitational field, and she also can detect the gravitational field.

speaker: Chris
text: She can tell which way is down toward the center of the Earth by the force acting on her feet.

speaker: Chris
text: And that measurement is taking place in Alice's brain.

speaker: Chris
text: So in Alice's brain, there's a representation of which way is up, and that's the internal reference frame of Alice that lets her do the experiment.

speaker: Chris
text: If she was freely floating in space, but the apparatus was anchored to the gravitational field, she wouldn't be able to tell that it was anchored to the gravitational field.

speaker: Chris
text: That's Einstein's point that Einstein makes in all of those experiments where he has observers flying around in spacecraft that they have to have their own reference frame.

speaker: Chris
text: What Einstein didn't emphasize was that reference frame is in their head.

speaker: Chris
text: It's encoded by their nervous system.

speaker: Chris
text: So I think it was Daniel who said this exactly correctly, that the physical object in her head, the the actual neural network that tells her which way the gravitational field is, is itself a semantic object.

speaker: Chris
text: That's what gives the word up and down meaning for Alice.

speaker: Chris
text: What do I mean when I say the word meaning?

speaker: Chris
text: I mean, it lets her take some action.

speaker: Chris
text: Semantics boils down to actionability if it gives things significance.

speaker: Chris
text: And this was the point that Bateson was making when he said, differences that make a difference for an organism, something is meaningful if it actually makes a difference for what I can do in this world that I'm trying to survive in.

text: So I'll leave it at that.
